utterances: You know, looking at some of these excerpts, they're difficult for a non-military person perhaps to understand and to break down some of the jargon and language.
Is there a way you can help those who want to read them to understand what it is they are reading?
Well, yeah, there is some jargon, there is some - I mean, you know, the military is filled with jargon.
And the number of acronyms and jargon in these reports is greater than most.
But the thing to keep in mind about these reports is that they're really focusing on the sort of bombs-and-bullets part of the war.
They're focused on what gets blown up and who gets killed and who gets shot and how many rounds of ammunition are being spent.
And the thing is that in a fight like Afghanistan, those are often the metrics that matter the least, okay?
Well, let's explore that for a moment, because I'm not sure how the loss of life would be something that you could consider to be not as important as something else.
What else would be more important than that?
Well, look, of course, every life is precious.
I'm not saying that the lives aren't important.
But what I'm saying is is that counterinsurgency isn't just about who shoots who.
Counterinsurgency is a contest, right?
It's a contest between the militants and the government and, you know, we're sort of there on the government's side.
It's a contest that includes everything from armed coercion to political persuasion.
And these documents only really cover the coercion, the armed coercion part.
They don't cover, you know, did a farmer bring his crops to market?
Are the local cops corrupt?
How's the local government doing?
Who do the people trust?
Those are the kind of key, key questions that guys like David Petraeus really count on to find out how the insurgency or counterinsurgency is going.
And they're not the kind of things that are conveyed in these reports.
Now, there are said to be 90,000 pages of these documents.
How much of it have you read?
(Soundbite of laughter)
A very small fraction of it.
But I did look at all the documents that pertain to the unit that I was with, Echo Company of the 2/8 Marines.

Now, overall, would you say that while there are discrepancies or omissions in terms of what you saw based on the experience that you had with Echo Company, does it give you a sense that maybe there are other and larger omissions elsewhere throughout that maybe undermine the veracity of this?
I wouldn't term it as omissions.
I'd term it more as, you know, this is one piece of evidence in a larger group of evidence if you want to learn about the war.
You know, this there's nothing in here that's I don't think that's that it's lies or, you know, willful omissions.
It's just that it's a very small slice of a much larger picture.

It's been several months since the community of Ferguson, Missouri, was rocked by the killing of unarmed 18-year-old Michael Brown by a police officer.

This weekend, activists planned new protests, calling for justice in the case that is still being reviewed by a grand jury.
St. Louis Public Radio's Camille Phillips was at today's march in downtown St. Louis and joins me now.
Camille, organizers were hoping to get people from around the country to come support demands for justice in the aftermath of the death of Michael Brown.

Well, they did have a good turnout.
There were people from New York.
There were people from Chicago.
Lots of people coming in from out of town.
But there was a lot of people from the St. Louis area as well.
I counted at least a thousand.
There could've been upwards of 2,000.
It's hard to say.

Oh, yes.
It was definitely peaceful.
